utterances: Chuck.
Thanks a lot.
Thanks a lot for the call.
Let's see if we can go now to - this is on the Republican line, Terry(ph).
Terry with us from Hartford, Connecticut.
Yeah, hi.
Thanks for accepting my call.
Sure.

You know, one thing which is interesting to me - and I hope that not only the Republican Party but everybody who learns - is that Barack Obama and his ability to use media technology and media fundraising is the way of the future and the McCain campaign certainly fell very short and I think lost the vote on that.

But my major issue is - or major concern was that as a white male - you know, I was very concerned when I heard that people were picking at the issue of the Bradley affect because white voters wouldn't vote for Barack Obama strictly because of his race and I was hoping that we could be above the race card in this day and age.
And I think, in some respects, the opposite thing occurred because looking at demographics this morning, I saw - I think the statistics was 96 percent of African-Americans voted for Barack Obama.

Well, certainly, he had a great appeal and in fact with the number of people who came out for this election, my feeling was that whoever won, it was truly the nation's decision because so many people came out to vote.
But I was concerned to see such a high percentage of African-American voters voting for Barack Obama.
It seems that the race card, in some respects, came out.
Well, they voted from strictly based on race and not solely on issues.
Andy, what is the normal percentage of African-Americans who would vote for a Democratic candidate regardless of his race?
About 90 percent.

I mean, I think that more African-Americans did vote for Barack Obama unquestionably and more registered to vote and more voted than in previous elections, a record number, and it's not too surprising.
This is a historic election.
The first black candidate - major black candidate, African-American, people tend to vote along their personal lines especially groups that haven't experienced power.

But what we can draw from this is, is that while we, analysts worry that race would be a negative factor in this campaign, actually, it was a positive because of the boost that Obama got, not only from African-Americans but from many whites who were interested - thought it was very important that an African-American candidate be elected.

I'm not saying they vote - they were voting for him purely along those lines, but that offsets that small - relatively small percentage of whites who said race was a factor and they went overwhelmingly for McCain.
So I think in the end, race mattered and it was probably more of a plus for Obama than a negative.
Terry, thanks for the call.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
So you're concerned that this will be a one-term presidency and be deemed a failure.
Well, certainly, I'm not sure how much of a honeymoon that Barack Obama can expect.
He did win decisively last night.
He can declare that he does have a mandate of some degree, Ken, but certainly the (unintelligible) are going to start coming very fast and furiously.

Well, except that there were so many overwhelming problems that almost seem too big for anyone one man or woman to deal with as a president, so I suspect a honeymoon will be there and I suspect that there will be efforts by both parties to at least (unintelligible) behind some kind of a solution, perhaps on energy then maybe later on, you know, other things that are concerning American.
Fair amount of overlap on the two parties on energy.
But you know something, 2010 seems like a long time away, but it starts tomorrow.
It starts immediately.
They have already - as a matter of fact, on CNN before, they said - a woman said, I don't know if Sarah Palin could be considered the front runner for 2012.
I said, oh, my God, we're not talking about 2012 yet.
But I mean, obviously there will be some kind of a honeymoon, some kind of effort to get things to - both parties to work together.
But you know at some point, politics will take over.
Yeah.
But one thing, we need healthcare, and I don't think the, you know.
There's not a lot of overlap on the two parties on healthcare.
That's going to be a difficult one, especially with the financial situation, the way it is, it's going to be expensive no matter which plan you look at, it was going to be awfully expensive.
All right.
Thank you.
Thank you very much for the call, Guy.
And here's an email question for Ken.
This is from Diane in Intervale, New Hampshire.
What's up with the Ted Stevens' race?
Well, as I've said before, I mean, you know, with - there's about 90, you know, somewhat percent, he's still ahead by several thousand votes and it's pretty remarkable.
Perhaps it's the Sarah Palin effect.

Perhaps it's the fact that in reality, no Democrat has been elected senator in Alaska since 1974, and Ted Stevens said, look, you know, I wasn't really convicted or I was convicted by a corrupt jury or unfair jury and I think they bought it, which is very interesting.

Don Young also, who is under FBI investigation, a Congressman from Alaska, has like a 52-46 point lead with not many votes to count, and so, for the rest of the country, it was a Democratic year, but not in Alaska, it seems like.
We're looking at what happened yesterday, who won, where and why.
Our guests, of course, NPR political editor Ken Rudin and Andrew Kohut who is the director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press.
They're both kind enough to be with us here in Studio 3A today.
If you'd like to get in on the conversation, we have split lines today.
Republican, McCain supporters, call 800-344-3893; Democrats 800-344-3864.
Stay with us.
We'll be back after a short break.
You're listening to a day after election special from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is an election special from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
And here are the headlines on some of the stories we're following here today at NPR News.
President-elect Barack Obama began work today to assemble a political transition team, a day after he defeated Republican John McCain.
President-elect Obama saw his two daughters off to school in Chicago, and got some exercise, and then got down to work.
And voters in California approved the measure to ban gay marriage overturning a state Supreme Court decision.
Opponents about a legal challenge with the city of San Francisco, saying it would look into the validity of the ballot measure.
Details on those stories and of course much more coming up later today on All Things Considered.
Tomorrow, we'll bring you another election special called Talk Of The World.
We hope to hear from those of you on our worldwide audience about the election of Barack Obama, in Europe, Africa, Asia, Latin America.
What has changed for you?
Guests include Natan Sharansky and Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.
That's tomorrow in this hour on election news special.
Throughout his campaign, Barack Obama promised to bring change and hope to America.
Both themes played a major role in his first speech as president-elect.

President-Elect BARACK OBAMA (Democrat, Illinois): This is our time to put our people back to work and open doors of opportunity for our kids, to restore prosperity and promote the cause of peace, to reclaim the American dream and reaffirm that fundamental truth that out of many, we are one; that while we breathe, we hope; and where we are met with cynicism and doubts and those who tell us that we can't, we will respond with that timeless creed that sums up the spirit of a people.
Yes, we can.
(Soundbite of crowd cheering)
President-Elect OBAMA: Thank you.
God bless you.
And may God bless the United States of America.
Barack Obama, the next president of the United States, ending his speech last night in Chicago's Grand Park.
Many voters cast their ballots for change, so if this is a new beginning, what begins and what ends?
Give us a call, Republicans, 800-344-3893; Democrats, 800-344-3864.
Our guests, both here in Studio 3A, are Ken Rudin, NPR's political editor and Andy Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press.
Andy, did anything surprise you last night?
Well, I was surprised by how well Barack Obama did in personal terms.
I mean, the economy shaped, to a large extent, the Democratic victory.
But when the exit polls correspondents were asked, which candidate has the right judgment, the gap had been at the beginning of the campaign so much in favor of John McCain.
In this exit poll, 58 percent said that about Barack Obama, only 49 percent said that about John McCain.
Obama not only won the campaign on the issues but he won it pretty convincingly in terms of the kind of person he was and in terms of instilling more confidence than John McCain.
To a certain extent, you could argue that John McCain may have lost some of the confidence of the American public.
But certainly, Obama built it.
Let's get to another caller and let's go to Rich.
Rich with us from Little Rock in Arkansas on the Democratic line.
Hi, Neal.
Hi, Rich.
Go ahead, please.
And again tomorrow, NPR's Talk of the Nation becomes Talk of the World as we get opinions from around the globe on NPR worldwide.
Join us for that broadcast too and stay tuned to NPR for the latest developments in those races that are still outstanding.
This election isn't over - not yet.
I'm Neal Conan.
You've been listening to a day-after-election special from NPR News in Washington.
Just wanted to make a quick comment about the generational term that's been applied to Barack Obama and I want to say amen to that.
I am a charter boomer and now have college-aged son and daughter.

And they're responding to Barack Obama the same way that my generation responded to the Kennedys, and to Martin Luther King, and particularly his call to service, I think, strikes a core that runs deep in us all, and he is inclusive in that call.

And finally, Martin Luther King's, I Have a Dream speech, a big part of that was - of that dream was that the day would come when his children would be judged not by the color of their skin but the content of their character, and this day is historical, I would humbly submit in that I think that day has come.
Thank you very much for that comment, Rich.
It's quite interesting.
I wanted to ask Ken Rudin about that.
Obviously, we have seen a generational torch being passed.

It is the President Bush's father, the 41st president of the United States, the first president Bush who was the - going to be the last president of the United States to serve in the Second World War.
It's conceivable that John McCain will be the last major party presidential candidate to have served in the Vietnam War.
And now we have presidents younger than we are and that scares the heck out of me.
That's terrifying.
But you know something, the very interesting point.
I was watching last night and again worrying about what counties are going where and who's winning the House seats and being more clinical than emotional.

And yet, when you watch the tears roll down Jesse Jackson's face and you hear the rhetoric coming out of Barack Obama which sounded so much like Dr. King, it was just like the history - 1960 to 1968 - just hit you all over again watching the (unintelligible) last night.
And Grant Park of all places.
Absolutely where the Chicago Democratic Convention was.
And the words of Abraham Lincoln in the cadences of Martin Luther King.
It was quite interesting.
Let's get Jeannie(ph) on the line.
Jeannie calling us from Kansas City on the Republican line.
Hi.
Hi, Jeannie.

I am calling on the Republican line because I did end up voting for John McCain but I am one of those people who waited until I had put my ballot in the mail where military families voted absentee to decide.
Two things that I wanted to say.

As a Christian, you know we try to live - my family - we try to teach our kids this, to let no word come out of your mouth about what's going to be profitable for building up one another and that's been something that's been sorely lacking in this campaign.

And you know just talking to other friends, it breaks my heart when I hear the negativity that we heard surrounding this campaign even down in my home state with the Senate campaign that Elizabeth Dole just lost down there.
In North Carolina.
Yeah.
Yes, yes.

And then as a military family member, what we tried to tell our children and a spouse and now I have a 20-year-old son who is in the military, no matter who wins, this person is going to be dead and now brothers commander-in-chief and things that you say, strongly negative things beforehand make it really hard to do that.

So our children don't even know - I mean if they would ask us directly, I guess we would tell them; but you know we've talked to them about the issues but our children don't even know who we voted for.
Anyway, just the negativity and really wish that that could be changed.
I don't like saying that.
Andy, the negativity of this campaign - more and more voters every year say they're turned off by negativity yet negative campaigning we're told continues to work.
Well, it works in some campaigns.
It's not altogether clear that McCain's negative campaigning worked.
In fact, there was a fair amount of backlash to it to get to this point of coming together though.
I cannot remember a new president where we haven't had a period where the American public gets behind the new president at least for some period of time and gives him a honeymoon.

And given the nature of Obama - who he is, where the country is - it's inconceivable to me that Americans, except for very hard core group of people opposed to him along partisan lines, will not come together in January, February and some months into the future with a very positive attitude.
I wonder there's - and Jeannie, let me try this out on you.
There was an aspect of Barack Obama to his campaign where he was running not so much for head of government with policies and positions - he certainly had all of those.
But for head of state in those grand appeals to our better angels, to the eloquence that we heard last night, and I wonder did you hear that as well?
